bestBHT.bht: The breastplates of the horse riders are described as being red like fire, blue like smoke, and yellow like brimstone. These colors indicate the fire, smoke, and brimstone that emerge from the horses' mouths. The riders' heads resemble those of lions, accentuating their terrifying presence. This depiction portrays the powerful and fearsome nature of this cavalry unit.

Henry Alford: having breastplates red, as fire...blue, as smoke...and yellow, as brimstone"
literally, hyacinthine. The hyacinth of the Greeks is supposed to have been our dark blue iris
the heads of the horses [were] as heads of lions, and out of their mouths goeth forth fire and smoke and brimstone
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the fiery color of the breastplates answering to the fire which issued out of their mouths.
their dark, dull-colored breastplates correspond to the smoke out of their mouths.
brimstone-colored: answering to the brimstone or sulphur out of their mouths.
Albert Barnes: He fixed his attention on the appearance of the immense army - the horses and their riders, and proceeded to describe them as they struck him.

Those who sat on them had such breastplates. This was said to be composed of 'fire, and jacinth, and brimstone'; that is, the part of the body usually incased in the coat of mail had these three colors.
All this seemed to issue from their mouths - that is, it was breathed forth in front of the host, as if the horses emitted it from their mouths.
Marvin Vincent: Of jacinth [υακινθινους] . Uakinqov hyacinth is the name of a flower and also of a precious stone." (25 words)
The Hebrews as a pastoral race, did not need the horse; and, for a long time after their settlement in Canaan, dispensed with it." (24 words)
Proceedeth fire and smoke. Compare Virgil." (7 words)
Archibald T. Robertson: Nowhere else does John allude to his own vision, though often in Dan.
Πυρινος is an old adjective (from πυρ, fire), here only in N.T.
Both rider and horse are terrible.
John Gill: having breastplates of fire, and of jacinth and brimstone;... appeared as flaming sulphur
the heads of the horses [were] as the heads of lions: gaping and roaring for their prey
out of their mouths issued fire, and smoke, and brimstone; ... represents the firing of guns on horseback in battle

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse describes an army with horse riders wearing breastplates of fire, jacinth, and brimstone. These breastplates, which were red, blue, and yellow, represent the fire, smoke, and brimstone that came from the horses' mouths. The fiery color of the breastplates matched the fire that emerged from their mouths, while the dark color corresponded to the smoke. The brimstone-colored breastplates aligned with the brimstone or sulfur that also came out. The image of the horse riders with heads like lions and emitting fire, smoke, and brimstone portrays a terrifying and formidable sight.

This passage depicts an awe-inspiring army of horse riders adorned with breastplates in various colors — red like fire, blue like smoke, and yellow like brimstone. The colors of their breastplates correspond to the fire, smoke, and brimstone that emanate from their mouths. The riders' heads resemble those of lions, emphasizing their intimidating nature. This image suggests the formidable power and devastating impact of this fearsome cavalry.

The breastplates of the horse riders are described as being red like fire, blue like smoke, and yellow like brimstone. These colors indicate the fire, smoke, and brimstone that emerge from the horses' mouths. The riders' heads resemble those of lions, accentuating their terrifying presence. This depiction portrays the powerful and fearsome nature of this cavalry unit.

The breastplates worn by the horse riders are vividly described as being red like fire, blue like smoke, and yellow like brimstone. These colors symbolize the fire, smoke, and brimstone that emanate from the mouths of the horses. The lion-like heads of the riders enhance their fearsome appearance. Such imagery portrays a formidable and terrifying cavalry, emphasizing their power and dominance in battle.

The horse riders in this description don breastplates of fire, jacinth, and brimstone, whose colors reflect the fire, smoke, and brimstone that issue forth from their mouths. The breastplates are likened to the dark blue hyacinth flower and its precious stone counterpart, emphasizing their vibrant appearance. The heads of the horses are compared to those of lions, signifying their fierce and predatory nature. These vivid details paint a picture of a formidable and awe-inspiring cavalry, instilling a sense of fear and power.
